metadata.title: Country differences in hospitalisation, length of stay and admission to Intensive Care Units 1 due to SARS-CoV-2 infection: a rapid review of available literature 2 3

abstract.text: 27 Objectives: Coronavirus disease (COVID-19) caused by the SARS-CoV-2 virus is spreading 28 rapidly worldwise and threatening the collapse of national health care systems. The 29 development of effective resource models are critical for long term health planning. The aim 30 was to evaluate the available literature, to consider parameters affecting hospital resources,

31 to effectively guide health policy and planning. Design: A detailed search of the literature, 32 using Google Scholar, PubMED, MedRxiv and BioRxiv, was conducted for the time period 01-33 DEC-2019 to 04-MAY-2020; using appropriate keywords: resultant articles were scrutinised 34 in detail, and appraised for reported data pertaining to hospitalization and hospital length of 35 stay (LOS). Results: Disease presentation was described in China; 81 % mild, 14 % moderate 36 and 5 % severe. The experience, thus far, in Europe and the USA are suggestive of a higher 37 degree of severity. Initial reports suggest high hospitalisation and ICU admittance rates.

38 More recent reports from the ECDC lower this estimation. Perhaps the relative age, the level 39 of pre-existing conditions, and other health factors may be contributors to differences. Data 40 from Irish cases suggest hospitalisation rate may be lower in parts of Europe and time 41 dependent. Hospital LOS is described in seventeen articles, with median lengths of stay 42 between 4 and 25 days. The evidence regarding the LOS in ICU is reported in eighteen 43 studies, fifteen deemed relevant. The majority of studies report ICU LOS between 7 to 10 44 days. Many of these studies are likely skewed towards shorter stay due to study cut-off 45 dates. Indications based on ICU LOS reported for patients continuing care suggest median 46 ICU stay will be longer. Conclusions: These parameter estimates are key to the development 47 of an effective health care resource model. Based on our rapid appraisal of the literature, is 48 it essential that Europe manages mitigation measures to ensure that hospital and ICU 49 capacity does not become overwhelmed to manage this pandemic long term.

body_text.text: latest work by Stier et al. (2020) emphasizes population density, with attack rates increasing 130 with city size.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Preparedness is key and resource matching to clinical requirement essential. Previous work 133 (Rhodes et al., 2012) suggests a large variation in availability of critical care bed in the EU / 134 EEA area, ranging from 29.2 in Germany to 4.2 critical care beds per 100,000 population in 135 Portugal. Perhaps this is key to understanding the difference in coping between different EU 136 countries. Clearly too, differences will exist between cultures, few western governments will 137 seek to use hospitalisation as a tool for quarantine. As the infection is spreading across the 138 world; this rapid review paper considers parameters affecting hospital resources resulting CC-BY-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 16, 2020 . . https://doi.org/10.1101 4 th May 2020. The search engines Google Scholar, PubMED, MedRxiv and BioRxiv were used, 157 using the following keywords: ("Novel coronavirus" OR "SARS-CoV-2" OR "2019-nCoV" OR 158 "COVID-19") AND ("length of stay" OR "duration of stay" OR "hospital stay" OR "ICU"). No 159 restriction on language was imposed as long as the abstract was available in English.

body_text.text: Eighteen studies relating to hospital LOS and fifteen studies or reports relating to LOS in ICU 189 were selected for detailed scrutiny as they each reported summary estimates with a 190 corresponding variance. The Italian report (COVID-19 Surveillance Group, 2020) was the only 191 report without an estimate of variance that was considered for detailed scrutiny, as the 192 study population was significant (n = 25,452). Preliminary estimates of severity were collated based on the analysis of data from EU and 228 EEA countries and from the UK. As expected some data were incomplete or missing in TESSy.
The eight update (ECDC, 2020a) indicates that 48,755 of 152,375 (32 %) were hospitalised 230 based on data from 26 European countries; with a country median 28 % (IQR 14 to 63 %).

Severe presentations that required ICU and or respiratory support accounted for 2,859 of 232 . CC-BY-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity. (which was not certified by peer review)

Death occurred in 1,005 of 9,368 (11 %) of hospitalized cases 235 from 21 countries (3.9 %, IQR 0 to 13 %). Age-specific risk increased among those 60 years 236 and older, thus consideration to age profile within a country is important. The latest report 237 on 23 rd April reported increased rate of hospitalisation with a pooled estimate of 42 %

body_text.text: The literature pertaining to length of ICU stay due to COVID-19 is reported in Table 3,   286 including eighteen studies and reports. Figure 4 illustrates the median (and IQR) ranges of 287 length of stay in ICU for relevant articles. In this figure, fifteen studies are presented; Three 288 case studies were excluded due to small numbers of relevant cases (Chen et al., 2020;  289 Kujawski et al., 2020; Young et al., 2020) . Median lengths of stay in ICU between 7 to 10 days 290 were observed in studies based in China (Cao et al., 2020; Fan et al., 2020; Yang et al., 291 20202; Zhou et al., 2020) . European studies conducted by Graselli et al. (2020)

The cause of the differences 334 in disease presentation between countries is not clear. Perhaps differences in case 335 definition, the relative age of the population, the level of pre-existing conditions within the 336 . body_text.text: The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 16, 2020 . . https://doi.org/10.1101 experience in Italy, thus far, suggests that must carefully manage mitigation measures to 338 ensure ICU capacity is not reached or breached. However, another major influencer on 339 hospitalisation rate will be the definition of a suspect case and the extent of COVID-19 340 testing within the community; the detection of a greater number of milder cases, diagnosed 341 within the community will ultimately influence the hospitalisation rate. The influence of 342 community testing is becoming evident in Ireland; as April progresses, it is clear in each 343 subsequent HPSC report (2020a; 2020b; 2020c; 2020d) that the rate of hospitalisation and 344 proportion of patients admitted to ICU is reducing. This is evidence perhaps that a broader 345 case suspect definition and a wider testing approach will impact the overall rate of

body_text.text: Superiore di Sanità, 2020) reporting the median hospital stay of 5 days for cases that did not 356 require ICU level of care. However, no range or confidence interval is described by this 357 report. Similar to the shorter duration of hospital stay in Italy, a more recent study 358 conducted in the USA, which examined hospital records of 5,700 sequential admissions to 359 New York hospitals, reported a short length of stay, median 4.1 days (IQR 2.3 to 6.8). body_text.text: Length of stay post ICU is illustrated in a figure in some small case series; and as such, were 408 data were not extracted for reporting or discussion in this review.

Limitations associated with any rapid review are pertinent to this study. A narrow aim was 412 set, namely to determine rate of hospitalisation and the length of stay in hospital due to 413 COVID-19 infection in countries across the world now at the centre of the pandemic. The

body_text.text: The length of stay in hospital outside of the ICU setting, due to COVID-19 is highly variable in 435 the literature, with median estimates varying from 4 to 25 days. Studies diverged in their 436 inclusion criterion. It is likely that the aim of hospitalisation varied among countries.

Discharge criteria is divergent in different jurisdictions, whether it related to a patient 438 required to test negative prior to discharge or where there was pressure to free up 439 . CC-BY-ND 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 16, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.05.12.20099473 doi: medRxiv preprint overcrowded hospitals. Indeed it is likely that some countries used hospitalisation to ensure 440 quarantine.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: As the pandemic spreads rapidly throughout the world, more and more evidence regarding 443 the length of stay in ICU following COVID-19 is reported. Many of these reports indicate a 444 median ICU length of stay between 7 to 10 days; however a number of these studies report 445 length of stay based only on resolved cases, and as such duration of stay it is likely skewed 446 towards a short stay due to bias towards those who have completed their ICU stay and are 447 now discharged or have died. Thus the upper estimates of the range should be considered 448 for use in resource models. It is apparent too that the data generated by each individual 449 country during the initial months of the outbreak will be critical to estimate the parameters 450 used for any national resource model.

FIGREF0.text: 139 from infection with SARS-CoV-2 beyond the evidence published from China. The objective is 140 to evaluate the current scientific literature from across the developed world with the overall 141 aim to influence health policy and support evidence-based decision-making. The proportion 142 of patients hospitalized due to infection with SARS-CoV-2 infection is discussed. The 143 proportion of patients who required critical or ICU care is outlined. Time spent hospitalised; 144 both in a general and an ICU setting is considered. For those who have been admitted to an 145 ICU, the length of time pre ICU, the length of time in ICU and the length of time post ICU to 146 discharge or death was collated from available literature. These estimates are central to 147 national resource modelling, which are being developed to aid policymakers to ensure 148 optimal resourcing during this pandemic. follows the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-153 Analyses-Extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR) checklist (Tricco et al., 2018). A 154 comprehensive search of the scientific literature and national and international government 155 .

FIGREF1.text: 161 inclusion. Inclusion criteria for 'the proportion of cases hospitalised' were papers that 162 reported the proportion of hospitalised and proportion of those hospitalised accessing 163 higher level care including critical care and intensive care unit (ICU) care. Inclusion criteria 164 for 'length of stay' (LOS) included articles that reported length of hospital stay, length of stay 165 in ICU, length of stay prior to admission to ICU, and articles that referenced length of stay 166 post discharge from ICU to a general hospital setting. Each article was assessed briefly for 167 suitability for inclusion in this study. Papers that did not report length or duration of time in 168 hospital or in ICU were discarded. The latest governmental reports from the Health 169 Protection Surveillance Centre (HPSC), Ireland, and from the Intensive Care National Audit 170 and Research Centre (ICNARC, 2020a), UK were consulted after the 4 th May cut-off. and reports that described the proportion of COVID-19 positive cases 174 hospitalised, the proportion of cases that were admitted to higher level care including 175 critical or ICU care, the length of hospital stay or the duration of hospital stay or length of 176 time in critical care or ICU were scrutinised in detail, and appraised for reported data and 177 quality of the scientific evidence. Parameter estimates for the length of stay in non-ICU or in 178 an ICU setting from the relevant articles were recorded and evaluated.

FIGREF3.text: and supplemented by manual search by LL, again with parameters 183 identified and recorded. (iii) Finally, the review was then internally reviewed by an additional 184 three members of the team (SM, DB, MC), and cross-referenced with other parameter 185 synthesis documents being developed by the group (all authors). Details of the resultant list 186 (n = 179), which included published and pre-printed articles, were entered in an Excel file.

FIGREF4.text: the daily number of notified cases and deaths for all countries and 196 Territories worldwide was downloaded in Excel format from the European Centre for 197 Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) and may be accessed at: 198 https://www.ecdc.europa.eu/en/publications-data/download-todays-data-geographic-199 distribution-covid-19-cases-worldwide. Data was imported into STATA version 14 (STATA 200 Corporation, USA). Cumulative cases and deaths were generated for each calendar day for 201 countries of interest, and expressed as a percentage of cumulative deaths to cumulative 202 cases. The crude mortality rate was expressed as a percentage over time, from day of 203 outbreak, defined as the day on which the tenth case was reported,

FIGREF5.text: 2.1 Length of stay in hospital (Non-ICU)274A summary of the literature pertaining to length of hospital stay in non-ICU settings due to 275 COVID-19, by country, is reported inTable 2. The overall length of hospital stay is reported in 276 eighteen studies or reports, with overall median lengths of stay between four days and 277 twenty-five days.Figure 3illustrates the median (and IQR) ranges of hospital length of stay 278 for relevant articles.

FIGREF12.text: .2.1 Length of stay in hospital (Non-ICU) 350 The overall length of hospital stay varied between 4 and 25 days among studies; two of 351 these studies were case series based on the observations of 10 (Lo et al., 2020) or 12 352 (Kujawski et al., 2020) patients, a further article (Linton et al., 2020) was based on data 353 extracted from publically available datasets. The studies are very diverse in their reporting 354 and presentation of hospital length data. The largest study is an Italian report (Instituto

FIGREF13.text: 360 hospital length of stay varies dramatically among different studies. Perhaps differences in 361 hospital capacity, overcrowding, government policy, funding source and other factors might 362 .

FIGREF14.text: York and describes the death of 14.7 % of ED only patients; patients who died in the 366 emergency room prior to being admitted to hospital. Given the large variation in length of 367 stay and the difference between continents; the studies relating to hospital LOS outside an 368 ICU setting were not appropriate to use to calculate a central tendency. 369 370 4.2.2 Length of stay in hospital (ICU)371Studies fromChina (Cao et al., 2020;Fan et al., 2020; Yang et al., 2020;Zhou et al., 2020) 372 report median ICU stays of 7 to 10 days. Similar median lengths of stay have been reported373 in Italy. The Italian report (COVID-19 Surveillance Group, 2020) dated 29 th April 2020 374 describes median LOS of 8 days if admitted to an ICU setting (n = 25,452); however, actual 375 length of time in ICU and proportion or number of patients cared for in ICU were not 376 specified. Important too, to note, this report while including a large number of cases, only 377 includes those who have died, and hence will not reflect the possible longer stay of 378 survivors. Another Italian study conducted by Grasselli et al. (2020b) reports the median 379 length of ICU stay was 9 days (IQR 6 to 13 days) for 1,581 patients. A Swiss study, too, 380 outlined the median length of stay was 9 days for 41 patients followed to discharge (Ceruti 381 et al., 2020). It is noticeable that length of ICU stay is more variable in US studies. In 382 particular studies that breakdown length of stay into those completed stay compared to 383 patients continuing care. It is evident that care must be taken with interpretation, continuing 384 care groups are reported to have longer stays; median LOS of 11.4 (Petrilli et al., 2020); 14 385 (Bhatraju et al., 2020); and 23 days (Argenziano et al., 2020) are outlined. A smaller case 386 series conducted by Valente-Acosta in Mexico highlights this continuing care group; this 387 study describes a case series of 33 patients admitted to ICU in Mexico city, the median LOS

FIGREF15.text: 399to transfer to ICU, some of whom were diagnosed based on clinical findings. Given the 400 timing of the study so early in the outbreak and the lack of consistency regarding the 401 diagnosis, these data should be discounted when considering future resources. Only the UK 402 ICNARC report (2020a) details useful data pertaining to length of hospital in Europe. Median 403 length of hospital stay pre admission to ICU for laboratory confirmed COVID-19 patients (n = 404 8,233) was 1 day (IQR 0 to 3 days), indicating the short duration before stepped up care 405 need is identified in COVID-19 patients.

FIGREF16.text: the literature may be limited by the time-limited constraint of gathering relevant 415 literature (less than five weeks). However, this rapid approach was necessary, given the aim 416 was to provide evidence-based estimates of length of hospital stay to steer policy and 417 provide parameter estimates for utilisation within a hospital resource model. Inclusion of 418 articles in this review was assessed based on the subject being reported in the article and if 419 the numbers of cases were considered relevant. Another shortcoming was some of the 420 available literature is in pre-print form and only undergoing peer review. the severity of case presentations have been described between continents; 424 and Ireland should base its expectation on those cases observed in Europe thus far in the 425 pandemic. Advice from the ECDC suggests hospitalisation rates of up to 42 % can be 426 expected. Additionally, we must expect increased level of care requirements, to critical care 427 and ICU levels, in up to 3 % of cases to allow for spare capacity, as mitigation measures are 428 relaxed in our jurisdiction. There is no doubt that the case definition in use and the 429 availability of community testing will determine the hospitalisation rate within a country. In 430 countries where community testing has been significant, we can expect the rate of 431 hospitalisation and the proportion requiring ICU level care to be lower. Preliminary data in 432 Ireland certainly supports this assertion.

TABREF0.text: https://www.hpsc.ie/a-209 z/respiratory/coronavirus/novelcoronavirus/casesinireland/epidemiologyofcovid-19inireland/. Data were entered into Excel, then imported into STATA 14 to generate the trends in cumulative cases, percentage of known cases hospitalised and the percentage of confirmed cases admittance into ICU over time. A summary of available scientific literature from the outbreaks worldwide relating to the 217 proportion of COVID-19 cases requiring hospitalisation and the need for stepped up medical 218 care, including critical care and ICU, by country, is presented in Table 1. Data from 33 studies 219 or reports are presented.European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC updates)The European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (ECDC) collates the laboratoryconfirmed cases reported to the European Surveillance System (TESSy) and thus far has 226 published nine update reports as the situation unfolds across Europe (ECDC, 2020a; 2020b).

TABREF1.text: 160,485 of 381,410 cases); based on data from 19 countries, however the country median 239 was 28 % (IQR 16 to 39 %). Severe presentations that required ICU and or respiratory Again, hospitalisation increased with age, and for males from 30 years. The242 changes over time in the crude mortality rate for all notified cases since day of outbreak, defined as the day on which the tenth case was notified, for selected European countries is 244 presented in Figure 1. Admission rates to ICU in the USA varied between 4.9 to 11.5 % (CDC COVID-19 Response Team, 2020) report. Myers et al. (2020) indicated 8.7 % ICU admission in a study conducted 251 in California in March. While Lewnard et al., (2020) observed a higher ICU admission rate 252 (25.6 %) also in California. A number of studies conducted in New York outlined ICU admission rates of 14.2 % (Richards et al., 2020); 22 % (Cummings et al., 2020); 23.6 % 254 (Argenizano et al., 2020); and 36% (Paranjpe et al., 2020). Of significance, are the mortality 255 rates in hospitalised groups (and specifically not ICU only groups) reported in a number of US 256 studies: 15.4 % Lewnard et al., (2020); 15.6 % Myers et al., 2020; 21 %; Richards et al., 2020; 21 %; Argenziano et al., 2020; and 29 % Paranjpe et al 2020.

TABREF2.text: ). Daily epidemiology reports compiled by the Health Protection Surveillance Centre (HPSC, 2020a) with data to March 30 th reports a hospitalisation rate of cases by 4 th May (HPSC, 2020d). The rate of admission to ICU reduced, concomitantly, from May 4th. The reports collated by the HPSC (HPSC Epi Team, 2020) in Ireland indicate that 268 proportion of hospitalisations and transfer to ICU increased occurred with age.

TABREF3.text: 10 days. Earlier reports from the ICNARC (2020b) indicated shorter LOS for ICU patients,

TABREF4.text: Length of hospital stay prior to transfer to ICULength of hospital stay prior to transfer to ICU due to COVID-19, by country, is presented in Four studies made reference to time in hospital prior to ICU transfer, including two small case series(Young et al., 2020; Kujawski et al., 2020). A long median hospital stay prior to transfer to ICU was described by Fan et al. (2020; median 8 days, IQR 4 to 11 days). The

TABREF5.text: No eligible studies outlining the length of stay post discharge from ICU were discovered.The relative variation in disease severity is very clear in the published literature from China; 81 % mild presentation, 14 % moderate presentation with 5 % severe or critical presentations that require high-level on-going care in critical care beds or within the ICU environment (Wu and Grogan, 2020). Nevertheless, the experience, thus far, in Europe and the USA would suggest some countries are experiencing a higher degree of severity of COVID-19 being reported. Early indications from Italy suggested hospitalisation rates of 30 % and admission to ICU between 16 to 18 %(Cereda et al., 2020;Graselli et al., 2020). While the eight update report from the ECDC (ECDC 2020a) restates this but suggests based on data from 16 EU countries that respiratory and or ICU support is needed in 2.4 % of cases; the latest ECDC report (ninth Update; ECDC 2020b) revises this slightly country specific

TABREF6.text: group is only n = 4. The authors of the UK ICNARC (2020a) report clearly highlight the influence of bias towards shorter stay; with both survivor and non-survivor groups reported 391 to have a median LOS of 8 days (ICNARC, 2020a). Indeed earlier reports from INCARC 392 (2020b) reported shorter LOS of ICU patients, as fewer persons had progressed through to completion of treatment. It is evident that study cutoff, and short follow ups, have influenced reported ICU LOS; it is clear that the influence of continuing care groups will lengthen length of ICU stay somewhat in time.
